journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Parametric studies of spur gear lubrication performance considering dynamic loads

article-meta.aff: 1School of Engineering, University of Warwick, UK
2State Key Laboratory of Mechanical Transmission, Chongqing University, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Huaiju Liu, School of Engineering, University of Warwick, Coventry CV4 7AL, UK. Email: huaijuliu@qq.com

abstract.p: Effects of friction excitation and gear backlash on spur gear lubrication performance, i.e. minimum film thickness, maximum pressure, etc. are investigated by considering the dynamic loads due to excitations of mesh stiffness, friction between gear tooth, and backlash. Dynamic loads are obtained using a semi-definite two-degree-of-freedom lumped-parameter model. Reduced Reynolds technique is applied to develop a lubrication model capable of dealing with any potential ‘asperity contacts.’ Varying spur gear geometry parameters and the Ree–Eyring fluid behavior are taken into account. Results show that friction excitation has a very limited influence on the dynamic load and hence on the lubrication performance. Backlash affects the dynamic load significantly but has a limited influence on the minimum film thickness. Maximum pressure increases with the value of backlash due to the direct relationship of pressure and load.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the development of the elastohydrodynamic lubrication (EHL) theory and the mixed lubrication theory, lubrication performances of spur gears have been investigated by many researchers. Dowson and Higginson1 studied the effect of gear parameters on film thickness using their empirical film thickness formula. Wang and Cheng2 adopted a Grubin-type analysis and obtained the minimum film thickness along the line of action (LOA). Hua and Khonsari3 introduced the transient squeeze effect into the gear lubrication model. Larsson4 then took the non-Newtonian effect of a limiting shear strength into account in the transient lubrication analysis of an involute spur gear. He showed that the transient effect is significant, especially at the areas where the shift in the number of tooth in engagement occurs. Wang et al.5 further considered the thermal effect, but they assumed the Newtonian fluid behavior. It is noted that those studies assumed smooth tooth surfaces. Li and Kahraman6 proposed a mixed EHL model of spur gear tooth contacts using measured surface roughness profiles. The transient squeeze effect as well as the non-Newtonian effect are taken into account which makes this model the most complete model for the evaluation of spur gear lubrication performance. However, they still did not consider real dynamic loads, which may differ significantly from the assumed quasi-steady load distribution.

It seems that parametric studies of spur gear lubrication performance have been studied extensively and intensively. For instance, effects of the speed and the load have been mentioned by Dowson and Higginson, and it is convenient to see their effects directly through curve-fitted minimum film thickness formulas such as the Dowson–Higginson one7 (1)hm=2.65reqU0.7G0.54W-0.13 where hm is the minimum film thickness, req the equivalent radius and U, G, and W the dimensionless speed parameter, material parameter, and load parameter, respectively.8 However, we should be quite careful in applying those minimum thickness formulae into spur gear applications because the speed and load effects are not independent (in other words, the load parameter W is a function of the speed parameter U) due to gear dynamic responses. Gear dynamics generate from the excitations of mesh stiffness variations, fluctuations of external load and rotation speed, gear backlash, manufacturing errors, assembly errors, etc. Wang and Cheng2 considered dynamic loads with a rotation dynamic model, but ignored the transient squeeze effect which does not sound a complete way to study the dynamic load effects. Very recently, Li and Kahraman9 proposed a way to investigate the effect of dynamic behavior on lubrication performance for a spur gear system. They proposed a methodology for gear dynamic lubrication modeling and developed a very complete dynamic gear lubrication model considering all sorts of transient effects, backlash, time-varying stiffness, and manufacturing errors. Conclusion has been made that the dynamic effect cannot be neglected at the resonance (or super-harmonic) resonance areas for EHL performance evaluation. However, even though people realize that dynamic load effect of a gear system should be considered when evaluating contact performance, a quantity study of influence of gear parameters, such as backlash, friction between the engaged tooth, etc. are not investigated by researchers. These parameters may cause variation of load distribution along LOA during meshing, which will further affect the lubrication performance of the engaging gear pair. In this study, effects of friction excitation and backlash on spur gear lubrication performance are studied by considering dynamic loads using a lumped-parameter model. Lubrication performance is mainly evaluated from minimum film thickness as well as maximum pressure. The proposed line contact lubrication model is capable of dealing with the so-called ‘asperity contacts’ using the reduced Reynolds technique proposed by Hu and Zhu.10 The Ree–Eyring non-Newtonian fluid behavior is considered by deriving the Reynolds–Eyring equation.11

sec.title: Dynamic model
sec.p:
The dynamic transmission error (DTE) of the gear pair, used to calculate the dynamic force, could be computed as the response of a non-linear, mass–spring oscillator,12 as shown in Figure 1. Taking the friction excitation and the clearance-type backlash into account, the semi-definite two-degree-of-freedom system could be represented by a single-degree-of-freedom system with the DTE x as the variable (2)mex··+cx·+k(t)f(x)=(T1+Tf)/rb1 where me is the equivalent mass and is expressed as (3)me=I1I2/(I1rb2 2+I2rb1 2) where I1 and I2 are rotation inertia of the pinion and the wheel, respectively, and rb1 and rb2 the base radius of the pinion and the wheel, respectively. Figure 1.
Spur gear lumped-mass model.

The damping ratio c is often determined empirically due to the lack of measurement data and proper models. In this study, the value 0.1 is allocated to the damping ratio, as the same one used by Ozuguven and Houser13 and Atanasiu et al.14 T1 is the pinion torque and Tf the friction torque. At the single-tooth-pair engaging part, it is generated from the single-tooth-pair friction torque Tfa, while at the double-tooth-pair engaging part, it also incorporates the second-tooth-pair friction torque Tfb. Considering the backlash as a clearance type, the expression of f(x) can be given as15 (4)f(x)={x-b,x>b0,-b<x<bx+b,x<-b where b is defined as the backlash.

The mesh stiffness is calculated using the potential energy method which was first proposed by Yang and Lin.16 Mesh stiffness could be curve fitted into the Fourier series form, as shown in Figure 2. Also shown in this figure is its frequency spectrum. The mesh stiffness excitation exhibits a mesh frequency component and its super-harmonic frequency components. Figure 2.
Gear mesh stiffness time history and frequency spectrum.

The dynamic factor, defined as the ratio of the dynamic mesh force to the static mesh force is used to get the dynamic tooth load, if the quasi-steady tooth load distribution is known. This way of calculating the dynamic single tooth load was also used by Tamminana et al.17 and Li and Kahraman9

sec.title: Lubrication model
sec.p:
The EHL model mainly consists of the Reynolds equation, the film thickness equation, the force balance equation, the pressure–viscosity equation, the pressure–density equation, etc. and has been fully developed and can be found elsewhere.18 However, standard EHL numerical models are not able to deal with the potential ‘asperity contacts’ that may be caused by surface roughness or sudden load change. In this study, the reduced Reynolds technique proposed by Hu and Zhu10 is applied to deal with any potential ‘asperity contacts’ due to the local drop of film thickness within the nominal Hertzian contact region. The Ree–Eyring non-Newtonian fluid behavior is considered using the Reynolds–Eyring equation proposed by Conry et al.11 The model is discretized using the same scheme proposed by Venner,19 and the dimensionless calculation domain is divided into equal-spaced 1025 points which makes the mesh dense enough if no surface features are considered. Time discretization scheme is chosen to be the same as the one used by Larsson and the dimensionless time interval ΔT is controlled to vary in the region ΔT/ΔX∈(2,5) in order to capture any transient effect caused by the load variation and fluid squeeze effect. The convergence criteria for any moment is chosen as
where Pi is the updated pressure and Pi ' the old pressure value at the point Xi. Detailed information about the lubrication model could be found in Lie et al.20

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Gear and lubricant parameters required for the lubrication model and the determination of dynamic loads are listed in Table 1. Under the fixed torque, the root mean square value of the dynamic error could be obtained by solving the dynamic model numerically. Figure 3 shows the result for the no-backlash case. It can be seen that main resonance occurs at the mesh frequency fm coinciding with the natural frequency fn. For the gear pair sample, the resonance input speed is n1 ≈ 8392.6 r/min. This characteristic speed is a little higher than most engineering speeds; hence, more popular speed cases are chosen, i.e. n1 ≈ 4196.3 and n1 ≈ 419.6 r/min, which correspond to fm = fn/2 and fm = fn/20, respectively. The dynamic response with n1 ≈ 4196.3 r/min is stronger than the one with n1 ≈ 419.6 r/min, which can be seen from the dynamic factor shown in Figure 4 by assuming the backlash zero. Figures on the left represent the time history of the dynamic factor in a mesh cycle while those on the right the frequency components. For the n1 ≈ 4196.3 r/min case, the dynamic factor may exceed 1.5 during meshing and the frequency components correspond to the integral multiples of the mesh frequency. However, for the n1 ≈ 419.6 r/min case, the dynamic factor is quite close to unity due to the low input speed and the frequency components are more fruitful than the n1 ≈ 4196.3 r/min case. The effect of all excitations, i.e. the mesh stiffness variation and the friction excitation are limited because the mesh frequency for n1 ≈ 419.6 r/min is far away from the resonance frequency. The two speed cases will be used in the following discussions. Figure 3.
RMS value of DTE with no backlash and μ ≡ 0.08. RMS: root mean square and DTE: dynamic transmission error. Figure 4.
Dynamic factor with no backlash and μ ≡ 0.08. . Table 1.
Gear parameters.
Number of pinion teeth N1 = 28
Gear ratio i = 3
Module m = 0.003175 m
Pinion pitch radius r1 = 0.0445 m
Gear width B = 0.02 m
Pressure angle α = 20°
Oil viscosity at ambient pressure η0 = 0.04 Pa s
The pressure–viscosity coefficient α = 2.2 × 10-8 Pa−1
Equivalent dynamic mass me = 0.46 kg
Comprehensive Young’s modulus E = 2.308 × 1011 N/m2
Eyring stress τ0 = 3 MPa
Input torque T1 = 100 Nm
Profile modification No
Error caused by manufacturing and assembling No

Figure 5 shows the result for the case with backlash b = 30 µm. Compared with Figure 3, the result for the case with no backlash, it could be seen that the backlash introduces a non-linear effect at mesh frequency around the natural frequency. This means that teeth impact may occur at this speed regime. For the two speed cases studied, n1 ≈ 4196.3 and n1 ≈ 419.6 r/min in following sections, linear characteristic remains and the non-linear effect could be ignored. Figure 5.
RMS value of DTE with b = 30 µm and μ ≡ 0.08. RMS: root mean square and DTE: dynamic transmission error.

sec.title: Effect of friction
sec.p:
Gear tooth contact friction has been investigated extensively. In early days, gear friction coefficient was predicted without taking the lubrication into account.21 With the development of the EHL theory, it is possible to obtain a more accurate friction coefficient prediction by calculating the traction force generated by the film, such as empirical formulae proposed by Jacod et al.,22 Xu et al.,23 and Li and Kahraman.24 Generally, predicted friction coefficient values with lubrication consideration are smaller than those values without taking lubrication into consideration, as can be seen in Figure 6. In order to investigate the effect of friction excitation on gear lubrication performance, four cases are investigated: no friction, constant friction coefficient μ ≡ 0.08, the Benedict–Kelley formula, and the Li–Kahraman formula. With the assumption of no backlash, the dynamic factor variations in a mesh cycle using the four friction excitations are depicted in Figure 7, with n1 ≈ 4196.3 and n1 ≈ 419.6 r/min. It can be seen for both the speed cases that the dynamic factor varies very slightly for the four friction cases. Other speed cases are also studied which show similar effects of friction on dynamic loads. Hence, it is believed that very little dynamic load difference could be caused by different friction excitations and very limited influence on the lubrication performance, i.e. pressures and film thicknesses, etc. would be caused by changing friction excitation ways. Figure 6.
Friction coefficient predictions along LOA. LOA: line of action. Figure 7.
Dynamic factors with no backlash.

It is reminded, however, that even though friction excitation has a limited effect on the lubrication performance, it does not mean it is negligible for a comprehensive spur gear working performance evaluation. Friction still constitutes the most contribution for the power loss and surface heating of the gear pair. Besides, friction excitation may affect the off-LOA motion significantly.25 Velex and Cahouet26 also revealed that important alternating bearing forces could be caused by tooth friction at low speeds.

sec.title: Effect of backlash
sec.p:
For most spur gear applications, backlash is often reserved to avoid being jammed due to heat inflation and to allow lubrication between the engaging tooth pairs. Gear backlash would cause a significant dynamic response and most of the relevant studies focus on effect of backlash on non-linear behaviors.15 In this study, backlash value with b = 0, 10, 20, and 30 µm are studied to see its effect on dynamic loads, as shown in Figure 8. For both speed cases, the backlash affects the dynamic factor significantly. With the increase of the backlash value, the dynamic factor also increases. For the case with b = 30 µm, the dynamic factor may exceeds five, which indicates dynamic load would be five times the original quasi-steady load. Using dynamic loads, lubrication solutions, i.e. minimum film thickness, maximum pressure, etc. could be obtained. Figures 9 and 10 show minimum film thickness with n1 ≈ 4196.3 and n1 ≈ 419.6 r/min, respectively. As a comparison, dashed lines represent solutions without transient squeeze effect consideration, as the way treated by Wang and Cheng.2 It can be seen that solutions taking squeeze effect into account differs significantly from the ones without squeeze effect consideration. Even though the backlash effect is quite strong for dynamic loads, it does not cause large differences in the order of magnitude of minimum film thickness. This could be explained by checking the Dowson–Higginson minimum film thickness formula (equation (1)). The exponent of the load parameter W is small, indicating a less effect of load on the minimum film thickness. For n1 ≈ 4196.3 r/min, solutions of the four backlash values give a minimum film thickness of around 0.5 µm, while for n1 ≈ 419.6 r/min, solutions of those four backlash values give a minimum film thickness of around 0.15 µm. However, the location where minimum the film thickness occurs may differ for the four cases. Figure 8.
Dynamic factors in a mesh cycle with μ ≡ 0.08. . Figure 9.
Minimum film thickness along LOA with n1 ≈ 4196.3 r/min. LOA: line of action. Figure 10.
Minimum film thicknesses along LOA with n1 ≈ 419.6 r/min. LOA: line of action.

Figures 11 and 12 show maximum pressure with n1 ≈ 4196.3 and n1 ≈ 419.6 r/min, respectively. For both speed cases, the maximum pressure differs significantly with different backlash values. This is easy to understand because from the Hertzian contact theory, the pressure is directly related with the load. With the increase of the backlash value, dynamic load increases, which further leads to a higher maximum pressure. For both cases, maximum pressures in the vicinity of the pitch point are higher than the ones in the vicinity of the areas far away from the pitch point along LOA. This is because in the vicinity of the pitch point, the load is carried only by a single-gear tooth pair. Figure 11.
Maximum pressure along LOA with n1 ≈ 4196.3 r/min. LOA: line of action. Figure 12.
Maximum pressure along LOA with n1 ≈ 419.6 r/min. LOA: line of action.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Effects of friction excitation and gear backlash on the spur gear lubrication performance, i.e. the minimum film thickness and the maximum pressure, etc. are investigated by considering the dynamic loads due to excitations of the mesh stiffness, the friction between gear tooth, and the backlash. Dynamic loads are obtained using a semi-definite two-degree-of-freedom lumped-parameter model. Friction excitation effects are studied by comparing cases with no friction, constant friction coefficient μ = 0.08, Benedict–Kelley empirical formula and EHL-based Li–Kahraman formula. Reduced Reynolds technique is applied to develop a lubrication model capable of dealing with any potential ‘asperity contacts.’ In the lubrication model, spur gear geometry parameters and the Ree–Eyring fluid behavior are taken into account. The following conclusions are made.
Friction excitation has a very limited influence on the dynamic load because it affects little in the LOA direction. Hence, when evaluating the spur gear lubrication performance, the friction excitation could be neglected.
Backlash affects the dynamic load significantly but has a limited influence on the minimum film thickness. Maximum pressure increases with the value of backlash due to the direct relationship between the pressure and the load. This indicates that when one evaluates the film thickness for a spur gear pair, the backlash effect could be neglected, while for pressure, much simpler Hertzian contact theory could be used to see the effects of the backlash.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant no. 51175523).
